choices.text: Cytotoxic T cells
B cells
NK cells
Helper cells

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cells

 

Cytotoxic T cells: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, typically derived from intracellular proteins, to cytotoxic T cells (also known as CD8+ T cells). When a cytotoxic T cell recognizes an antigen presented by MHC class I on the surface of a cell, it is activated to destroy the infected or malignant cell.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. B cells: B cells are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and by direct interaction with helper T cells (CD4+ T cells), not by MHC class I.

 

Option C. NK cells: Natural Killer (NK) cells do not rely on MHC class I molecules for activation. In fact, they often target cells with low or absent MHC class I expression, which is a common strategy of infected or transformed cells to evade cytotoxic T cells.

 

Option D. Helper cells: Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on APCs, not by MHC class I.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the arrow in the given transverse section of the thorax. (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

 

The given image represents a cross-sectional view of the thorax, and the structure marked by the arrow is identified as the pulmonary trunk. The key points to identify the pulmonary trunk are its location and the surrounding structures in the thoracic cross-section.

 

  • Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel that arises from the right ventricle of the heart and bifurcates into the right and left pulmonary arteries. It is situated anterior to the aorta and is clearly visible in the image as a large tube dividing into two branches.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carina: The carina is the point at which the trachea bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. It is located lower in the thoracic cavity and is not associated with the structures visible in the image.

 

Option B. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is located to the right of the sternum and is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option D. Arch of Aorta: The arch of the aorta is the curved portion of the aorta that gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. In a cross-sectional view, it appears as an elongated structure, not as the large round structure marked by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given CT image. (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumatised superior turbinate

 

The superior turbinates form one of the three pairs of conchae in the nose and represent part of the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone, arising as bony projections from its posterior surface.

 

The air passage between the superior nasal concha and the lateral nasal wall is known as the superior meatus and forms part of the nasal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatisation of the superior turbinate, indicates the presence of air spaces within the turbinates, which can have implications for nasal physiology and potential sinus pathologies.

choices.text: Topically applied sulfonamide antibacterial
Topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Opioid receptor agonist

questions.text: Dorzolamide is a: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

 

Dorzolamide is a topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It helps in decreasing the rate of formation of aqueous humor in the eye, therefore useful in the management of glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topically applied sulfonamide antibacterial agents include silver sulfadiazine, Mafenide acetate, sulfacetamide etc.

 

Option C. Second-Generation Sulfonylureas are oral antidiabetic agents which act via increasing sensitivity of the insulin receptors and stimulate the release of insulin from the pancreas. It is used to manage type-2 diabetes mellitus. It includes Glipizide, Glyburide etc.

 

Option D. Opioid receptor agonist is the class of drugs which bind to the opioid receptors in the body. It includes Morphine, Pethidine, Fentanyl etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dorzolamide is a topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing the production of aqueous humor, making it effective in the treatment of glaucoma. This distinguishes it from sulfonamide antibacterials, second-generation sulfonylureas, and opioid receptor agonists, which are used for different medical conditions.

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is correctly identified as a branch of the maxillary artery, which itself is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus by providing the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Also a branch of the maxillary artery, the septal branch of the greater palatine artery participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: This artery, a branch of the facial artery (which originates from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System –

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

Generalized symptoms of fever, productive cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis along with chest x-ray showing multiple cavitation lesions are suggestive of tuberculosis. This diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • Chest X-ray: Presence of multiple cavitary lesions, which are characteristic of pulmonary TB.
  • Biopsy Findings: The presence of granulomas, multinucleated giant cells (Langhans type), and caseous necrosis is indicative of TB, which involves granulomatous inflammation with a distinctive type of necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener's Granulomatosis: This could also present with nasal deformity and granulomas but is usually associated with vasculitis and lacks the caseous necrosis typical of TB.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Can cause nasal collapse ("saddle nose") but typically does not present with the lung involvement seen in TB.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Also presents with granulomas but lacks the caseous necrosis seen in TB and typically shows non-cavitary lung lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis should be considered in patients presenting with respiratory symptoms, systemic signs, and nasal deformities when accompanied by histological evidence of caseating granulomas. This constellation of findings is distinct in suggesting TB over other granulomatous diseases.

 

Granulomatous Disease of the Nose:

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

When otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are absent, it indicates a potential cochlear pathology, specifically affecting the outer hair cells. Further testing is required to assess the extent and nature of hearing loss, as well as to rule out any retrocochlear pathology.

 

2. Tympanometry: This test assesses the condition of the middle ear and tympanic membrane mobility by creating variations in air pressure in the ear canal. It is useful to determine if the absence of OAEs might be related to middle ear issues, such as fluid, which can mask cochlear function.

 

4. Speech Audiometry: This test evaluates the ability to understand speech and also provides information about the clarity of speech perception. It helps to determine the speech recognition threshold and is crucial for diagnosing the degree and type of hearing loss when OAEs are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure Tone Audiometry: While this test is crucial for determining the threshold levels of hearing and the degree of hearing loss across different frequencies, it was not specified as one of the correct responses in this context.

 

3. Free Field Audiometry: Generally used for young children or individuals who cannot reliably use headphones, this test measures hearing sensitivity to sounds presented in an open field. However, it requires a controlled sound field, which is not always practical for immediate follow-up when OAEs are absent.

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 29

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about the clinical pediatric case as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate

 

 

 

The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which is a tumor located at the base of the coccyx in newborns. It is the most common tumor in neonates, and its origin and characteristics are well understood.

 

  • Persistence of Primitive Streak: Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak, not from the prochordal plate. The primitive streak is a structure in early embryonic development that usually regresses, but if remnants persist, they can lead to the formation of these tumors.
  • Defective Migration of Primordial Cells: This statement is correct as primordial germ cells that fail to migrate properly to the genital ridge can contribute to the formation of teratomas.
  • Contains Skin, Cartilage, and Bone: Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Therefore, they can contain a variety of tissue types including skin, cartilage, and bone.
  • Benign Tumor of Coccyx: Sacrococcygeal teratomas are generally benign, although they can sometimes be malignant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge: This statement is correct. Defective migration can result in teratomas.

 

Option C. Contains skin, cartilage, and bone: This statement is correct as teratomas can contain these tissues.

 

Option D. Benign tumor of coccyx: This statement is correct as sacrococcygeal teratomas are often benign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak and can contain various tissues including skin, cartilage, and bone. They are typically benign tumors located at the base of the coccyx.

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. A stool examination was done, and it showed the presence of the organism shown in image A. The body has segments broader than the length. Which of the eggs shown in column B corresponds to this organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given image shows characteristic features of Hymenolepis nana. This can be identified by its body segments being broader than long.

 

The egg of hymenolepis nana is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore with 6 hooklets as seen in the image. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

 

Valsalva maneuver can lead to a temporary increase in blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system. This phenomenon can be explained by:

 

  • Increased Intrathoracic Pressure: By trying to exhale against a closed airway, you create increased pressure within your chest cavity. This can compress the large blood vessels.
  • Increased Sympathetic Activity: The increased intrathoracic pressure triggers the body’s sympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the “fight or flight” response. This leads to the release of stress hormones like adrenaline and norepinephrine. These hormones cause blood vessels to constrict (vasoconstriction), which further raises blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure: Incorrect. The pressure increase primarily affects the aorta and systemic circulation, not just the left ventricular pressure.

 

Option C. Increase in left atrial pressure: Incorrect. While there may be a slight increase in left atrial pressure, it is not the primary cause of the rise in blood pressure observed during the Valsalva maneuver.

 

Option D. Increase in left ventricular volume: Incorrect. The maneuver does not directly increase left ventricular volume; instead, it increases pressure within the thoracic cavity affecting the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

The rise in blood pressure at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is primarily due to the increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure, along with increased sympathetic activity.

choices.text: Restriction of water intake and wait and watch

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the initial management of the irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alpha blocker

 

Alpha blocker will be used for the initial management of the irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

 

Alpha blockers

 

  • Most commonly preferred ones are α1A blockers like Tamsulosin and Silodosin.

  • They do not lead to postural hypotension, which can be seen with selective α1 blockers like Prazosin, Doxazosin etc.

  • Later block α1 receptors in the blood vessels as well, leading to vasodilation.

  • However, these drugs have no effect on the size of the prostate gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restriction of water intake and wait and watch: While lifestyle modifications, including reducing fluid intake, may help manage symptoms to some extent, they are not sufficient for the initial management of significant irritative symptoms caused by BPH.

 

Option C. Prostatectomy: This is a surgical procedure to remove the prostate gland. It is typically reserved for severe cases of BPH or when other treatments have failed. It is not the initial management step.

 

Option D. Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP): TURP is a surgical procedure to remove parts of the prostate that are causing obstruction. It is effective but generally considered after medical management, such as alpha blockers, has been tried.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha blockers, particularly α1A blockers like tamsulosin and silodosin, are used for the initial management of irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia. These medications help alleviate symptoms by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urine flow without significantly affecting blood pressure.

questions.text:
First part of PCT has which of the following transport proteins? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Sodium potassium pump
  2. Na- glucose co-transporter
  3. Sodium hydrogen antiport
  4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1,2,3

 

1. Sodium-potassium pump: This transporter is found on the basolateral side of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) cells and is critical for maintaining the sodium gradient that drives other transport processes.

 

2. Na-glucose co-transporter: This is located on the apical membrane of PCT cells and uses the sodium gradient to co-transport glucose from the tubular lumen into the cell.

 

3. Sodium-hydrogen antiport: Also on the apical membrane, this antiporter exchanges sodium from the tubular lumen with hydrogen ions from the cell, playing a key role in sodium reabsorption and pH balance.

 

Other Option

 

4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter: It is present in the distal or late part of PCT (Not in the early PCT)- contributes to bicarbonate reabsorption.

The correct combination based on the provided answer is b) 1,2,3, which includes the sodium-potassium pump, the Na-glucose co-transporter, and the sodium-hydrogen antiport, all of which are essential for the function of the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal convoluted tubule – transport processes –

questions.text: Match the characteristics clinical features resulting from the compression of the listed structures in the event of thyroid enlargement. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation

 

  1. Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea.
  2. Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing.
  3. Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome: Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms.
  4. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

1-b . Transthyretin (TTR) or Prealbumin is a tetrameric transport protein highly conserved through vertebrate evolution and synthesized in the liver, choroid plexus, and retinal pigment epithelium. TTR transports the thyroid hormone thyroxine and the retinol-binding protein (RBP) bound to retinol (vitamin A).

 

 2-c. Transcobalamins are carrier proteins which bind cobalamin (B12). Transcobalamin I (TCN1), also known as haptocorrin, R-factor, and R-protein, is a glycoprotein produced by the salivary glands of the mouth. It primarily serves to protect cobalamin (Vitamin B12) from acid degradation in the stomach by producing a Haptocorrin-Vitamin B12 complex. Once the complex has traveled to the more neutral duodenum, pancreatic proteases degrade haptocorrin, releasing free cobalamin, which now binds to intrinsic factor for absorption by ileal enterocytes. Transcobalamin II (TCN2) binds cobalamin once it has been taken up by enterocytes of the terminal ileum and the "Intrinsic Factor-Vitamin B12" complex has been degraded. Transcobalamin II is then involved with the transport of Vitamin B12 to the tissues.

 

 3-d. Haptoglobin (abbreviated as Hp) in blood plasma, haptoglobin binds with high affinity to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, and thereby inhibits its deleterious oxidative activity. 

 

4-a. Hemopexin binds to free heme. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex will then be removed by the reticuloendothelial system (mostly the spleen).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct pairs are as follows:

 

1. Thyroxine - b. Pre-albumin

2. Vitamin B12 - c. Transcobalamin

3. Hemoglobin - d. Haptoglobin

4. Heme - a. Hemopexin

choices.text: A-1 B-2 C-3
A-2 B-1 C-3
A-3 B-2 C-1
A-1 B-3 C-2

questions.text: Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2 B-1 C-3

 

Dilutions of adrenaline (epinephrine) with their typical uses:

 

  1. 1:1000 dilution of adrenaline is more concentrated and is commonly used in the treatment of Anaphylaxis. It is administered intramuscularly in emergency situations for its rapid vasoconstrictive and bronchodilating effects.
  2. 1:10000 dilution is less concentrated and is typically used in the management of Cardiac Arrest. It's administered intravenously.
  3. 1:100000 dilution is used as an additive in Local Anesthesia. The vasoconstrictive properties of adrenaline help to prolong the action of the local anesthetic and reduce bleeding in the surgical field.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve?  (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Gluteus Medius

2. Gluteus Minimus

3. Tensor fascia lata

4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3

 

Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, S1) supplies to Gluteus Medius, Minimus and Tensor Fascia Lata (damage leads to positive Trendelenburg sign). Accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels, the nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. The superior branch accompanies the upper branch of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery to supply gluteus medius and occasionally gluteus minimus. The inferior branch runs with the lower ramus of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery across gluteus minimus, supplies the glutei medius and minimus and ends in tensor fasciae latae.

 

Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis (S1, S2).

 

 

1. Gluteus Medius: True. The gluteus medius muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve supplies motor neurons to the gluteus medius and plays a crucial role in the abduction and stabilization of the hip joint.
 

2. Gluteus Minimus: True. Similar to the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus muscle is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions in hip abduction and stabilization.
 

3. Tensor Fascia Lata (TFL): True. The tensor fascia lata muscle, often referred to as the TFL, receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This muscle assists in various movements, including flexion, abduction, and medial rotation of the hip.

 

Other Option

 

4. Piriformis: False. The piriformis muscle is not innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the nerve to the piriformis, which arises from the sacral plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor Fascia Lata receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, and S1 nerve roots). Piriformis, on the other hand, is innervated by one of the branch of sacral plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of action of vancomycin as shown in  the image below
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Vancomycin is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase. Therefore, in the above given image, it acts at the step 4. Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent used against gram positive bacteria.
 

Other options:


Option A. 1: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

 

Option B. 2: It is inhibited by Cycloserine. It is a structural analog of D-alanine and inhibits the enzymes alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine and d-alanyl-d-alanine ligase, thereby preventing the incorporation of D-alanine into the peptidoglycan chain.

 

Option C. 3: Bacitracin inhibits step 3 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation of the BP transporter which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin acts at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, thereby inhibiting further elongation and cross-linking of the peptidoglycan.

choices.text: Sporothrix schenckii
Staphylococcus aureus
Nocardia asteroides

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Although Staphylococcus aureus can cause various skin infections, including cellulitis, abscesses, and impetigo, it does not typically spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics in the characteristic pattern of lymphocutaneous spread. Staphylococcus aureus usually causes localized infections.

 

Other Options

 

Organisms that can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," which presents with nodular lymphangitis, characterized by lesions following the lymphatic drainage.

 

Option C. Nocardia asteroides: Nocardiosis can present with cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions that spread along lymphatics, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes swimming pool granuloma or fish tank granuloma, presenting with skin lesions that spread along lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective

 

While Sporothrix schenckii, Nocardia asteroides, and Mycobacterium marinum are known to spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, causing lymphocutaneous lesions, Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized skin infections and does not exhibit this pattern of spread.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Anaplasma phagocytophilum

questions.text: The inclusion body Rickettsial morula is found in neutrophils during infection caused by? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplasma phagocytophilum

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum is a bacterium known to cause the disease tick-borne fever (TBF) in domestic ruminants in Ixodes ricinus-infested areas in northern Europe. This organism infects granulocytes, particularly neutrophils, leading to the formation of characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies known as morulae.

 

During an infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum, light microscopy of blood smears taken in the initial fever period can often suffice for diagnosis. When these blood smears are stained with May-Grünwald Giemsa, the organisms appear as blue cytoplasmic inclusions within the neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: This bacterium causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which does not typically involve the formation of morulae in neutrophils. Instead, it causes endothelial cell infection leading to vasculitis.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: The causative agent of Mediterranean spotted fever, also does not typically form morulae in neutrophils. Like R. rickettsii, it primarily infects endothelial cells.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: This bacterium causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) and forms morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils. This distinguishes it from Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which targets neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes the formation of Rickettsial morulae in neutrophils, whereas Ehrlichia chaffeensis forms morulae in monocytes.

 

Mnemonic "GAME": Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis.

questions.text:
During a clinical examination, when the patient stands on the left foot, the pelvis tilts downward on the right side. Which anatomical structures are involved in this condition? (INICET NOV 2023)

 

 

 

  1. Superior gluteal nerve
  2. Gluteus minimus
  3. Gluteus medius
  4. Sciatic nerve
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

 

 

This question describes a clinical scenario where a patient is exhibiting a positive Trendelenburg sign. When asked to stand on the left foot, the patient's right side drops, indicating a problem with the muscles or nerves responsible for maintaining hip stability. The Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

 

1. Superior Gluteal Nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. Damage to this nerve can lead to weakness in these muscles.

 

2. Gluteus Minimus: This muscle, along with the gluteus medius, helps to stabilize the pelvis during walking. Weakness or paralysis of the gluteus minimus results in the inability to maintain a level pelvis.

 

3. Gluteus Medius: This muscle is crucial for hip abduction and pelvic stabilization. Weakness or paralysis causes the pelvis to drop on the side opposite to the stance leg.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve does not innervate the gluteus medius or minimus. Its primary functions involve the muscles of the posterior thigh and lower leg. Damage to the sciatic nerve would not cause a Trendelenburg sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Trendelenburg sign, where the pelvis drops on the opposite side when standing on one foot, indicates weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

choices.text: Nicotine gum

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is the most effective drug in smoking cessation. Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic receptors. It is one of the 1st line oral drugs that is used for smoking cessation. The other drugs are Bupropion, even Nicotine replacement in the form of gums, lozenge, patch, spray can also be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buspirone: Primarily used for the treatment of anxiety disorders, buspirone is not used for smoking cessation. Bupropion is used for smoking cessation.

 

Option C. Nicotine gum: As a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), nicotine gum helps to reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings by supplying a small amount of nicotine. While effective for many people, it may be less effective than prescription medications like varenicline, especially for heavy smokers.

 

Option D. Rimonabant: This drug was initially developed as an anti-obesity medication and was found to also have some effect on smoking cessation. However, it was withdrawn from the market due to psychiatric side effects, including depression and suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It works as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors, helping to alleviate withdrawal symptoms and reduce the rewarding effects of nicotine. This makes it a highly effective option for individuals seeking to quit smoking.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50 mL/hour

 

The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour.

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 700 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it, even though it occurs continually in all living humans. It is about 700 mL/day or 50 mL/hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal insensible water loss is approximately 50 mL/hour, resulting from evaporation through the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drug acts by inhibiting the synthesis of the marked layer shown by arrow in the image?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isoniazid

 

Isoniazid is activated by Catalase Peroxidase and it acts by blocking the mycolic acid synthesis. It is a bactericidal drug that is effective against both intracellular and extracellular bacteria that are actively replicating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: It is the most bactericidal drug, that is effective against intra as well as extracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking RNA polymerase.


Option C. Pyrazinamide: It is also bactericidal, that is effective mainly against intracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking fatty acid synthase.


Option D. Ethambutol: It is a bacteriostatic 1st line anti-tubercular drug that acts against both intra and extracellular bacteria by blocking arabinosyl transferase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoniazid acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the mycobacterial cell wall, making it an effective first-line treatment for tuberculosis. The other first-line drugs have different mechanisms of action, such as inhibiting RNA polymerase (rifampicin), blocking fatty acid synthase (pyrazinamide), and inhibiting arabinosyl transferase (ethambutol).
